clinical_study.brief_title: Vitamin E for Oxaliplatin-induced Peripheral Neuropathy Prophylaxis
clinical_study.official_title: Randomized, Placebo Controlled Study of Vitamin E for Oxaliplatin-induced Neuropathy Prophylaxis

brief_summary.textblock: Introduction: Oxaliplatin (Ox) is a frequently used platinum-based medication that is a part of many chemotherapy regimens for the treatment of several gastrointestinal malignancies. One of the most important limitations to its use is the induction of both acute and chronic peripheral neuropathy (PN). Previous studies have shown that vitamin E can reduce the incidence of cisplatin-induced PN by 50%. In this study, the investigators aimed to determine if vitamin E could also prevent Ox-induced acute PN

detailed_description.textblock: This was a prospective, phase II, randomized pilot study. Patients were randomized 5 days before the start of Ox to receive either vitamin E at 400 mg daily or placebo, until after the end of the Ox-based chemotherapy regimen. The investigators evaluated PN intensity using the CTCAE version 3 and specific Ox PN gradation scales. The investigators included patients with colorectal and gastric cancers scheduled to receive Ox-based chemotherapy. Both groups received calcium and magnesium supplements before and after oxaliplatin infusions.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- ECOG Performance status 0 or 1
- Older than 18 years
- New diagnose with colorectal or gastric cancer
- Scheduled to receive oxaliplatin-based regimens
Exclusion Criteria:
- Excluded patients with a previous history of PN or with symptomatic PN at entry into the study
- Excluded patients who received other chemotherapy regimens (except isolated 5-fluorouracil)
- Patients currently receiving gabapentin, carbamazepine, amitriptyline, amifostine or multivitamins
